title: Privacy Policy
description: Policy The University of California, Riverside is committed to ensuring the privacy and accuracy of your confidential information to the extent possible, subject to provisions of state and federal law. Other than as required by laws that guarantee public access to certain types of information, or in response to subpoenas or other legal instruments that authorize access, personally-identifiable information is not actively shared. In particular, we do not re-distribute or sell personal information collected on our web servers.

title: Out-of-State
description: UCR believes that out-of-state students add an important and valuable depth to our campus. Our award-winning faculty will mentor you. Our diverse campus community will embrace you. And our dedicated resources will help you build your future! Sunny Southern California invites you to make the University of California, Riverside your home away from home.

title: Terms and Conditions of Use
description: Please Read These Terms and Conditions of Use Carefully Before Using This Site By using this site and all other registered UCR web sites, referred to as "these sites", you agree to these terms of use. If you do not agree to these terms of use, please do not use this site.

title: Staff
description: Staff members at UC Riverside take pride in working for an institution that continually creates meaningful experiences for all Highlanders — and is rising in the ranks of national prominence. UCR was ranked the fastest rising university in America by U.S. News in 2019 and in the Top 30 of institutions dedicated to the public good by Washington Monthly in 2018. We want to create something better — on our campus and beyond — and our inspiring and dedicated staff helps us do just that. Without a doubt, the work we do daily to create transformative change on local, national, and global scales could not be done without them. And just as our staff helps to build better tomorrows by supporting UCR’s mission of research, teaching, and public service, we empower them and encourage their success through our unwavering support, resources, and mentorship — and outstanding benefits. That includes being on a campus situated in an ideal locale for work-life balance: In addition to all the vibrant city of Riverside has to offer, it’s also just a short drive from exquisite mountains, desert, and the beach.

title: First Year
description: UC Riverside is ready to help you turn your passion into purpose. Our award-winning faculty will mentor you. Our diverse campus community will embrace you. And our first-year-specific resources will help you build your future!

title: Faculty
description: Faculty at UC Riverside thrive within America’s most prestigious public university system — and on one of the most dynamic campuses in the nation. UCR was America’s fastest rising university, according to the U.S. News 2019 rankings, and placed among the top 1 percent of universities worldwide, according to the 2018-19 Center for World University Rankings.  Our faculty members educate and elevate our students, our future leaders, while simultaneously creating visionary solutions and conducting path-breaking research of their own to address the greatest challenges facing our community and world. We make sure they have the resources, support, and stimulation they need to persevere. Among our distinguished faculty are two Nobel Prize winners, and 13 members of the National Academies of Science and Medicine. In fact, we are one of fewer than 20 public U.S. universities to boast multiple Nobel Prize winners on our faculty.  Every day, our diverse faculty bring an entrepreneurial spirit to education, showcasing what a public university is capable of in the 21st century. Through their interdisciplinary mindsets and shared commitment to collaborative inquiry, they are effecting the kind of transformative change that proves no barriers are too great at UCR.

title: New center to study labor issues in the Inland Empire
description: Inland Empire Labor and Community Research Center at UC Riverside is one of five UC centers meant to advance timely labor research.

title: Undergraduate Admissions
description: Bold Hearts. Brilliant Minds.

title: SIR Today!
description: This page will be the new launch for the My.UCR.edu log-in.

title: Current Students
description: At UC Riverside students of every background and ambition, from first-generation college-goers to dedicated graduate researchers, are encouraged to dream big — and achieve their dreams.  Our students make our campus community a great place to live, learn, and grow — sharing their ideas, identities, and sense of what’s possible to help propel us forward in the dynamic digital and cultural space of an increasingly interconnected world. UC Riverside offers its undergraduate students more than 80 majors, providing plenty of options to pursue the subject matter about which they are most passionate. And our drop-in tutoring and study lounges designed to accommodate a variety of learning styles, and impressive research library — one of the largest in the nation — ensure our students have everything they need to achieve their academic goals.

title: Undergraduate Admissions Statement of Privacy Practices
description: TRANSPARENCY REGARDING THE USE OF YOUR PERSONAL DATA As part of our commitment to protecting your privacy, this statement is designed to provide you with information regarding how UC Riverside (“UCR”) Undergraduate Admissions, part of UC Office of the President, collects and processes the information you share when you use our website located at admissions.ucr.edu, and each of its associated domains (together, the “Sites”), utilize the services of ours which include providing information to prospective UCR undergraduate applicant

title: LA Times executive editor is Hays Lecture Series speaker
description: Kevin Merida, executive editor of the Los Angeles Times, will be the speaker at the 54th Hays Press-Enterprise Lecture at UC Riverside. The May 9 lecture will be in person, on campus for the first time in three years. Merida, 66, took the helm of the largest newsgathering organization in the West in June 2021 and oversees the Times newsroom, as well as Times Community News and Los Angeles Times en Español.

title: Notable Alumni
description: 40 Under 40, UCR Launches Search for Innovative, Early-Career Alumni UCR's top-ranking education has given rise to a community of Highlander Alumni with exceptional career success, well-deserved accolades, and extraordinary achievements. The university has developed this new alumni recognition program to celebrate bold, industry-leading individuals working to change the world. The inaugural list will feature 40 of our exceptional alumni under the age of 40 and will be included in a special feature in the UCR Magazine issue for spring 2022.

title: Head men’s basketball coach Mike Magpayo signs 5-year contract extension
description: UC Riverside head men’s basketball coach and 2022-23 Big West Coach of the Year, Mike Magpayo, has signed a new five-year deal that will keep him at the helm of the Highlanders’ program through the 2027-28 season. Magpayo’s new contract comes on the heels of UCR’s best season in the program’s Division I history.

title: One year later: Surprises, disappointments in Ukraine war
description: This is a partial reprint from a UC Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation, or IGCC, retrospective on Russia's war in Ukraine. The retrospective featured UC Riverside faculty members Paul D'Anieri and Jana Grittersova, among other experts from the UC system.

title: Dining Services
description: Delicious | Nutritious | Sustainable

title: Citrus Grove Order Form
description: Send your event and lunch, dinner, and large reception orders to Citrus Grove Catering.

title: High-tech air quality research center dedicated in Riverside
description: The California Air Resources Board dedicated its new state-of-the-art Southern California headquarters Thursday, Nov. 18, on a 19-acre site near the UC Riverside campus. The 402,000-square-foot laboratory and office facility, located on land provided by UCR, is one of the largest and most advanced vehicle emissions testing and research facilities in the world, agency officials said.

title: How UCR became a national leader in enrolling Chicanx/Latinx students
description: The population’s growth over the last half century has been driven by students

title: Capturing daily life during the COVID-19 pandemic
description: UCR community’s photos, letters, and event information to be included in new library collection.

title: 4 UCR graduate students win grants to do research in the natural reserves
description: Projects include the study of aquatic insect communities, bumble bees, and the impact of climate change on plants

title: New NASA-funded program to train K-12 students in STEM fields
description: Outreach components include public lectures, parent nights, and telescope viewing opportunities

title: Grant to physicist gives study of strongly interacting systems a boost
description: A physicist at the University of California, Riverside, has received a grant of about $523,000 from the U.S. Department of Energy to study the possible emergent behavior of “strongly interacting systems,” an important area of focus in solid-state physics.  Specifically, when the repulsive Coulomb force between electrons in a solid becomes strong, new behaviors — not easily understood from knowledge of the microscopic laws of nature — are possible.

title: Grant funds study of sexual abuse in religious communities
description: Supported by $550,000, a team of researchers led by UCR's Amanda Lucia will examine why and how sexual abuse persists across a range of religious traditions

title: Grant addresses needs of students struggling in mathematics
description: Project led by UCR’s Asha Jitendra is supported by nearly $1.4 million from the U.S. Department of Education’s Institute of Education Sciences

title: Research to focus on small molecule that can help fight breast cancer
description: UC Riverside and City of Hope awarded Department of Defense grants for the collaborative project

title: Highlanders set season records, nearly sweep postseason awards
description: UC Riverside men's basketball earned numerous postseason awards following one of the most historic seasons in program history.  Mike Magpayo was named the Big West Coach of the Year, the first time in program history the award has gone to UC Riverside. Lachlan Olbrich was named Big West Freshman of the Year, while Jamal Hartwell was named the Big West Sixth Man of the Year.

title: California study finds that growing political conflict hinders learning and increases hostility
description: A new analysis by researchers at UC Riverside and UCLA shows that even in blue state California, political attacks on public schools are pervasive and growing, hindering learning and the role schools play in a diverse democracy.  Political division and community-level conflict is negatively impacting student interactions, and many California students are experiencing hostility and intolerance in school. Troublingly, the research finds high levels of hostile comments toward LGBTQ students, and racist remarks targeting Latino, and in particular, African American students.

title: Dining Services
description: Delicious | Nutritious | Sustainable

title: Older adults may achieve same cognition as undergrads
description: A set of recent studies demonstrates for the first time that learning multiple new tasks carries benefits for cognition long after the learning has been completed. The finding affirms a long-held assertion of the lead researcher, Rachel Wu, who is an associate professor of psychology at UC Riverside. That is, older adults can learn new tasks and improve their cognition in the process, if they approach learning as a child does.

title: Maria Hinojosa to deliver the 50th Hays Press-Enterprise Lecture
description: The April 9 event will feature the executive producer of “Latino USA,” a Peabody Award-winning show aired on NPR.

title: Highlander Pep Band surprises campus with hype song
description: Imagine you’re sitting in class on a random Thursday morning, listening to your chemistry professor, and then a 15-piece band bursts in the room blasting the Macklemore and Ryan Lewis throwback hit, “Can’t Hold Us” — but the tuba, symbols, trumpet, and flute version. If you were on campus on May 18, you didn’t have to imagine it because it happened in real life — and the UC Riverside Highlander Pep Band filled random locations around campus with music while a camera crew filmed crowd reactions.

title: UC President Napolitano meets with Moreno Valley students
description: University of California President Janet Napolitano met with a few hundred students at Rancho Verde High School in Moreno Valley on Friday, Nov. 2 to explain how a college education is within their reach.

title: Researcher honored for work in English language learner education
description: The James Irvine Foundation recognized Linda Navarrette as one of six change-makers in California.

title: Boozing while breastfeeding impacts health of newborns
description: Studies have shown that consuming alcohol during pregnancy can alter the brain and behavioral development of gestating offspring. Currently, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention advises against maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy and state that there is no known safe level of consumption. What are the consequences, however, of mothers consuming alcohol while breastfeeding? A research team at the University of California, Riverside, performed a mouse study to find out.

title: UCR among top 1% of world universities
description: UC Riverside retains its place among the top 1% of universities, according to the World University Rankings. The campus ranked No. 242 in the 2021-22 list of the top 2,000 out of 19,788 institutions worldwide. UCR was named No. 82 nationally and in the top 50 public institutions in the US.

title: UC Riverside research team fuels the hemp revolution
description: A new hemp pulping method that converts 100% of the plant to useful components moves toward commercialization

title: UC Riverside named to Top 50 Green Colleges list
description: UC Riverside was recently named among the Top 50 Green Colleges by the Princeton Review; ranking No. 16 among public universities and No. 48 overall in the nation. The Top 50 list is chosen from school-reported data and student opinions collected from online surveys. The survey questions canvass whether students experience a healthy, sustainable quality of life; how well the university is preparing students for “green” jobs; and the school’s environmental policies.

title: Mass customization can make fashion more sustainable if customers are willing to wait for it
description: High fees for disposal and recycling can boost the sustainable effect under some circumstances

title: Manganese in Central Valley water threatens fetuses and children
description: Water in California’s Central Valley contains enough manganese to cause cognitive disabilities and motor control issues in children, and Parkinson’s-like symptoms in adults.

title: Commencement 2022 to be in person and on campus
description: UC Riverside’s class of 2022 will celebrate the milestone of receiving their bachelor's, master's, and doctoral degrees in person and on campus. In early June, the campus will finally welcome graduating Highlanders to the commencement stage, where their friends, families, and fans can cheer them on as they cross the stage in their statement caps, crisp gowns, and commemorative sashes/stoles. Noteworthy details:

title: New multicampus consortium to study assembly of coronaviruses
description: Host campus UC Riverside will be joined by UC Davis and UC Merced

title: New method identifies adaptive mutations in complex evolving populations
description: UC Riverside study focused on how HIV mutates to escape the immune system

title: Connecting Classrooms to Congress
description: New social studies curriculum aims to boost civic education in a polarized nation

title: This is the dawning of the age of the vaccine passport
description: The vaccine passport is coming.

title: Immigrant Asian American women may be at higher risk for breast cancer
description: Research highlights differences in risk among Asian American women who immigrated versus their U.S.-born counterparts

title: COVID-19 expressions in video, art, poetry
description: A history assignment gave UCR students an opportunity to capture their lives during the pandemic.

title: The planet that could end life on Earth
description: A terrestrial planet hovering between Mars and Jupiter would be able to push Earth out of the solar system and wipe out life on this planet, according to a UC Riverside experiment.

title: Physicists explain how large spherical viruses form
description: UC Riverside-led study deciphers key elements for the assembly of a large virus; understanding its formation could contain viruses’ spread

title: Women on corporate boards increase company buyout value
description: The presence of women board members increased the value of companies targeted for acquisition by as much as 5%, study found.

title: UCR graduate students share why their research matters
description: 26 Ph.D. and master’s students visited with state lawmakers to give them firsthand insight into their work and why it merits more state investment

title: UC officials applaud Supreme Court's DACA decision
description: University of California officials applauded on Thursday the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision to strike down the Trump administration’s attempt to end a program that allowed 650,000 Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, recipients to live and work in the country.

title: Researchers warn of tick-borne disease babesiosis
description: UC Riverside and Yale University team sequences and mines genome of the pathogen Babesia duncani

title: COVID-19 lockdowns reduced disease spread but with costs
description: The lockdowns at the beginning of COVID-19 pandemic reduced the spread of infection by an estimated 56%, a recent study has found. If all governors did not issue any lockdowns until April 23, 2020, the number of cases would have been five times higher by April 30, 2020, the study asserts. But the lockdowns came with economic costs.

title: The shutdown brought bluer skies but more nighttime ozone to the Inland Empire
description: Air quality improvements lead to unique atmospheric chemical behavior

title: Striking a balance between immunity and inflammation
description: Focusing on hookworms, UC Riverside mouse study identifies role infection-fighting cells play in inflamed and damaged tissue

title: A possible end to ‘forever’ chemicals
description: Excess electrons could help break the strong chemical bonds in products that contaminate water supplies

title: From UCR’s garden to students’ tables
description: UCR’s community garden delivers fresh fruit and vegetables to students who remain on campus.

title: Removing the novel coronavirus from the water cycle
description: Scientists call for more research to understand whether water treatment methods kill the virus responsible for the COVID-19 pandemic

title: UC Riverside engineers are developing a test to rapidly identify body fluids at crime scenes
description: The disposable, low-cost tool will improve the speed and accuracy of investigations

title: Raising the bar through authentic research
description: Boil the water, add the ingredients, stir.  The instructions given in undergraduate science labs can feel a bit like making ramen noodles. “Lab courses that accompany many large science undergraduate lectures often adopt a cookbook-type approach, where students follow a series of instructions in a stepwise process without really understanding why they’re doing what they’re doing,” said Marsha Ing, an associate professor of educational psychology in the University of California, Riverside’s Graduate School of Education.

title: Political scientists make battleground state predictions
description: UC Riverside political science professors were polled on their predictions for eight battleground states, and the results carry some optimism for the Joe Biden camp.

title: Amir Zaki publishes 23 years of photography in new monograph, ‘Building+Becoming’
description: The book weaves stories that capture both nature and architecture. It goes on sale on April 26

title: ‘Forbidden City’ shines light on Mao Zedong’s dancing girls
description: Vanessa Hua’s latest novel "Forbidden City" explores the little-known history and influence of the teenage revolutionaries in Chairman Mao’s inner circle

title: Modern activities follow the contours of ancient Teotihuacan
description: Lidar mapping study reveals vast landscape modifications that still influence construction and farming

title: Still life in shades of gray
description: How Toni Morrison helped an economics professor turn grief into art

title: UC Riverside among Washington Monthly’s Top 30
description: University achieves high marks for social mobility, research, and public service

title: Getting high on worms
description: UC Riverside researchers show that in parasitic worm infection both the host and the worm produce cannabis-like molecules

title: UC Riverside receives Diversity Award
description: INSIGHT into Diversity recognition acknowledges recruitment, retention efforts for underrepresented, first-generation students and faculty

title: UCR receives its first cannabis grant
description: School of Medicine’s Nicholas DiPatrizio will lead a team tasked with assessing the impact of long-term cannabis exposure on metabolic health and disease

title: How mantis shrimp pack the meanest punch
description: Multifaceted design of the mantis shrimp club is inspiring advanced composite materials for airplanes and football helmets

title: Why mantis shrimp don’t crack under pressure
description: Cracking paradoxically improves fracture resistance in the pugnacious crustacean’s dactyl club

title: UC Riverside-led study sheds light on how IBD can develop
description: Inflammatory bowel disease, or IBD, describes Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis, two chronic diseases that cause inflammation in the intestines. IBD, which affects about 3 million adults in the United States, is an autoimmune disorder — a condition in which the body’s immune system attacks healthy tissues. Its symptoms include diarrhea, rectal bleeding, fatigue, weight loss, and stomach cramps.

title: How an autism gene contributes to infertility
description: UC Riverside mouse study shows how gene mutation leads to ovaries failing prematurely

title: Nanofiber filter improves rural water treatment
description: An electrospun nanofiber uniquely suited to removing nitrogen and phosphorous could help prevent nitrate contamination of drinking water in small, rural communities most at risk

title: An interview with UCR Engineering parents
description: Parent's of graduating electrical engineering student, Frances and Ruperd Wilson Sr. reflect on their son's time at BCOE.    Q: What inspired Ruperd to attend UCR and become an Electrical Engineer?

title: Computers, nematodes, and curiosity
description: Alejandro De Santiago Perez wants more lab experience before pursuing a doctorate in bioinformatics.

title: Juvenile incarceration has mixed effects on future convictions
description: Juvenile Incarceration is a double-edged sword and rehabilitation programs may improve welfare of convicted juveniles

title: Voters and multiracial candidates? It's complicated
description: There is a whole new dynamic that pundits, campaign managers, and voters will be negotiating in American politics, and the starting gun has already been fired. That is, the complicated — so says the research — dynamic of how voters regard multiracial candidates. On the national stage, it began with Barack Obama, and continues in this election cycle with Democratic nominee Joe Biden’s running mate, California U.S. Sen. Kamala Harris.

title: Why weren’t New World rabbits domesticated?
description: Archaeologists find the answer in rabbit social behavior

title: Agreement propels anthropological opportunities for UCR researchers, students in Mexico
description: Memorandum of understanding strengthens the relationship between UCR’s anthropology department and Mexico’s National Institute of Anthropology and History

title: Anthropologist plots new use for motion-capture technology
description: UCR bioarchaeologist Sara Becker plans to use the cutting-edge technique to document traditional labors of indigenous Andean people

title: UCR Ph.D. student curates Riverside Art Museum Exhibition
description: Running Feb. 3 through Dec. 30, 2018, the show features a selection of Mesoamerican artifacts on public display for the very first time

title: Bioengineering-led Neuroengineering Symposium brings more than 80 academic experts to share their advancement and build partnerships
description: UCR’s Department of Bioengineering led the campus’ first Computational Neuroimaging and Neuroengineering Symposium (CNNS) in November. The symposium brought together more than 80 cognitive neuroscientists, computational psychologists, bioengineers and neuroengineers, electrical and computer engineers, and computer scientists to discuss new advances and results in the fast-growing field.

title: Bioengineering to host an open house of its new Pediatric Rehabilitation Technology Lab showcasing advancements in pediatric assistive devices
description: The ability to move independently permits us to examine the world around us. Children born with motor impairments face unique challenges to learn about their environment and develop cognitively and socially through locomotion.  Innovative research in pediatric rehabilitative technologies allow children with these disabilities to interact with and explore their world in a way previously thought to be impossible.

title: Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering welcomes 17 new faculty
description: This year, UC Riverside’s Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering (BCOE) welcomed 17 new faculty members, bringing its total faculty cohort to 129. Among the additions are the new engineering dean, a distinguished engineering professor, three provost diversity fellows, a Fulbright Scholar, a National Science Foundation (NSF) CAREER awardee, and two assistant research engineers.

title: UCR among national leaders in degrees that 'pay off'
description: UC Riverside ranked No. 14 among universities nationally in CNBC Make It’s annual “50 Colleges that Pay Off the Most” list. Editors for CNBC Make-It, which is a business-news site, said the ranking carries greater weight due to scrutiny of higher education costs-benefits in the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Drug decreases gut leakiness associated with ulcerative colitis
description: UC Riverside-led study is the first to show how tofacitinib affects epithelial cells lining the gut

title: Drug found to correct gene defect that causes immune-driven gut leakiness
description: UC Riverside-led study is the first to show how tofacitinib rescues gut barrier function from overactive immune cells

title: Early opaque universe linked to galaxy scarcity
description: Team led by UC Riverside astronomer George Becker used the Subaru telescope to make the discovery

title: Electronic nose startup gets whiff of success
description: Chromanose chosen for National Science Foundation Innovation Corps entrepreneurial support

title: Electrons take one step forward without two steps back
description: Scientists use molecular dipoles to accelerate electron transfer in one direction and completely suppress it in the other. This “holy grail” of energy science could hasten the design of new and superb energy and electronic materials

title: Ten UC Riverside professors receive NSF CAREER awards
description: The awards support early career leaders in research and education

title: Report provides introduction to Inland Empire’s women
description: “State of Women in the Inland Empire” is the result of collaboration between UC Riverside’s Center for Social Innovation and Women’s Resource Center

title: Microbiome study suggests marine nematodes are not picky eaters
description: UCR research finding no relationship between nematode species and microbial profile suggests marine worms don’t have a restrictive diet

title: Report paints portrait of Inland Empire’s growing workforce
description: The region’s job growth exceeds the statewide average, and efforts are underway to ensure more good jobs that allow families to make ends meet

title: It’s not easy being green
description: Despite how essential plants are for life on Earth, little is known about how parts of plant cells orchestrate growth and greening. By creating mutant plants, UC Riverside researchers have uncovered a cellular communication pathway sought by scientists for decades.

title: Committee for accurate Inland Empire census count marks formal launch
description: When it comes to the 2020 census, every person counts; here’s why

title: Want to see California on the rise? Look inland
description: A new coalition headed by a UCR professor wants to change the way you think about the regions beyond California’s coast

title: Center for Social Innovation launches regional platform for public discourse
description: The SoCal Policy Forum platform is a collaboration between UCR and Southern California News Group

title: Simple experiment explains magnetic resonance
description: UC Riverside physics students design a table-top experiment for the classroom

title: Malou De Kergret Takes on Leadership Role
description: Forward Malou De Kergret is one-of-a-kind on the UC Riverside women's basketball team this season. She's the only senior. "Something is different about your senior year," De Kergret said. "All seniors from all sports feel it. You know it is your last year and you want to make a difference."

title: UCR bioengineer awarded Fulbright grant
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif. (www.ucr.edu) — A University of California, Riverside scholar has been awarded a Fulbright grant to conduct research at the University of Sao Paulo in Brazil for 2018-19.

title: ARTSblock exhibition features public’s work alongside artist’s
description: The Culver Center will host an exhibition featuring photography submitted by the community in conjunction with installations by Xavier Cázares Cortéz

title: Come say ‘barn voyage’ to beloved eatery before its renovation
description: The Barn will close June 14 for an 18-month renovation

title: Exhibition explores 20th Century through the lens of dust
description: A peculiar photograph leads to an examination of modernity, war, and ruin in “A Handful of Dust”

title: UC Riverside and Neuroscience Education Institute partner to deliver continuing medical education nationwide
description: Content developed by School of Medicine for physicians and other health care professionals includes grand rounds and a journal club delivered virtually

title: Latest rankings place UCR at No. 12 among U.S. colleges
description: UC Riverside jumped 20 places — to No. 12 in the U.S. and No. 9 among public universities — in a prestigious college ranking list published annually by Money magazine. As the trend of shifting formulas among the top rankings lists continues, Chancellor Kim Wilcox said UCR’s stature as a leading public university grows.  “It is deeply gratifying to see the national rankings systems having moved so profoundly toward recognizing what UCR does well: maintaining an environment of both research excellence and success for students of all backgrounds,” Wilcox said.

title: AAPI Data releases mapping tool for Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders
description: Ahead of census, UCR-based research initiative offers resource to better understand fastest-growing racial groups in U.S.

title: Indigenous philharmonic musicians will perform repertoire of mexican music
description: UCR will host four bands, all formed in Los Angeles by Mexican immigrants from the southern state of Oaxaca, Mexico

title: Picosecond electron transfer in peptides can help energy technologies
description: Hydrogen bonds reshape peptides to move electrons a million times faster than previously known

title: Back in camp: women's soccer
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — For UC Riverside women's soccer head coach Nat Gonzalez, this season's message is simple. It started all the way back in spring.

title: Scientists unlock genetic secrets of wine growers’ worst enemy
description: Following a decade-long effort, scientists have mapped out the genome of an aphid-like pest capable of decimating vineyards. In so doing, they have discovered how it spreads — and potentially how to stop it.

title: UCR Herbarium founder donates $900K to preserve its future
description: UC Riverside’s herbarium, established over 60 years ago, is an irreplaceable library of plant specimens.

title: $1.5 million gift creates Sean and Stella Harper Endowed Scholarship Fund
description: Sean Harper is the first person to admit he wasn’t the most disciplined student when he came to UC Riverside as a biomedical sciences student four decades ago. “I was still 17 for my first few weeks at UCR,” Harper said. “I knew that I wanted to study medicine but I wasn’t the most organized or prepared student. I had a lot to learn and my time at Riverside was transformative in that regard.”

title: UCR ecologists work toward post-fire rebirth of healthy landscapes
description: The worst fire impacts this year are predicted to hit Northern California’s higher elevation forests and Southern California’s chaparral-clad mountainous National Forest lands. To aid recovery, UC Riverside ecologists are collaborating with the US Forest Service to target these spots with new post-fire ecological restoration strategies.

title: New strategies to save the world’s most indispensable grain
description: A UC Riverside-led team has learned what happens to the roots of rice plants when they’re confronted with two types of stressful scenarios: too much water, or too little. These observations form the basis of new protective strategies.

title: Parasitic plants conspire to keep hosts alive
description: The plant that encourages kissing at Christmas is in fact a parasite, and new research reveals mistletoe has an unusual feeding strategy. When two mistletoes invade the same tree, they increase photosynthesis to get the nutrients they need, essentially sharing the tree and causing it less harm.

title: Some domesticated plants ignore beneficial soil microbes
description: Domestication yielded bigger crops often at the expense of plant microbiomes

title: What was behind 'vote switching' in the 2016 election?
description: Study pinpoints concerns about race and immigration — not economic ones — as likely determinants of vote switching

title: Engineering college interim dean to become dean at Drexel University College of Engineering
description: The interim dean of the Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering at UC Riverside will become the new dean of the College of Engineering at Drexel University in Philadelphia, beginning Sept. 1. Sharon Walker has been interim dean since July 2016, replacing Reza Abbaschian, who had been dean for 11 years, and who became director of the Winston Chung Global Energy Center at UCR.

title: This former cop wants to build trust between communities and police
description: Fulbright Scholar Roberto Rivera looks to Jamaica as a model of restorative justice

title: Small magnets reveal big secrets
description: Work by international research team could have wide-ranging impact on information technology applications

title: Focus on the Future: Women's Soccer
description: As freshman defender Katie Wong stepped onto the field for her first practice as a member of the UC Riverside women's soccer team earlier this month, she noticed some familiar faces. A local student-athlete from Corona, Wong played with forward Leigh Polson, midfielder Jen Barroso and forward Liz Chua on her club team. "I came into UCR feeling so comfortable because of all the people I know," Wong said. "I got even more excited when the time came to start practicing."

title: Experiencing police violence worsens mental health in distinct ways
description: Unique effects of police violence create a public health crisis for communities most affected

title: Study documents poor mental and physical health in rural borderland community members
description: UC Riverside-led study offers vivid picture of health consequences of life events and chronic strain among foreign-born Mexicans in farm working communities

title: Scientists honored by American Geophysical Union
description: Marilyn Fogel and Timothy Lyons will be honored as new fellows during December meeting

title: Omega centauri unlikely to harbor life
description: Close encounters between stars in the Milky Way’s largest globular cluster leave little room for habitable planetary systems

title: Scientists developing new solutions for honeybee colony collapse
description: The University of California, Riverside, is leading a new effort to stop and reverse a worldwide decline in honeybees, which threatens food security and prices.

title: After wildfires, do microbes exhale potent greenhouse gas?
description: Laughing gas is no laughing matter — nitrous oxide is a greenhouse gas with 300 times the warming potential of carbon dioxide. Scientists are racing to learn whether microorganisms send more of it into the atmosphere after wildfires.

title: In sexual conflict, ant queens prevail in evolutionary arms race
description: It’s hidden from sight, but there’s an epic battle of the sexes raging in the leafcutter ant species Atta colombica. Competing males deliver sperm in a fluid that’s toxic to rivals’ sperm, while females quash their efforts in order to ensure their own reproductive success.

title: Plant pathologist leads research to stop spread of citrus-destroying disease
description: UC Riverside’s Hailing Jin is principal investigator of USDA grant that also supports vaccine development to fight huanglongbing, or citrus greening disease

title: Australia enables UCR to dig into Earth’s wild past
description: Australian officials signed an agreement last night allowing UC Riverside to continue its pioneering research on a government-owned goldmine for unusual fossils. Nilpena Station is a city-sized plot of land in the Australian Outback. It harbors the richest collection on Earth of animal species around 550 million years old. Some of its fossil beds are the size of a tennis court and contain entire communities of organisms.

title: UCR to host California attorney general debate
description: Primary candidates Xavier Becerra, Steven Bailey, Eric Early, and Dave Jones will convene at UCR's Culver Center on May 15

title: Astronauts might soon grow SPACE tomatoes
description: Grant to UC Riverside could help put tiny tomato plants on the International Space Station

title: Pest-monitoring device enters into field trials
description: The technology invented by engineers at UC Riverside could reduce pesticide use and crop loss

title: Magnonic devices can replace electronics without much noise
description: Magnonic devices of the future could use low power to avoid performance losses

title: Pumpkins, trunk-o-treat, and family fun at UC Riverside
description: UCR’s Community Garden will host its inaugural Fall Festival and Pumpkin Patch on Oct. 26.

title: Product authentication at your fingertips
description: UC Riverside-led research brings rapid and reversible switching of plasmonic color to solids

title: New center to address health disparities in inland Southern California
description: Five-year, $16 million grant from the National Institutes of Health will help launch Center for Health Disparities Research at UC Riverside

title: New model links cultural trauma with health inequalities
description: UC Riverside researchers offer new interpretation of cultural trauma

title: Unfolding Black history at UCR
description: UCR has more than 4,400 degreed Black alumni, and is nationally recognized for having one of the smallest achievement gaps in the country.

title: Here are the many ways UCR is helping students right now
description: A list of available resources during this time of uncertainty.

title: Experts on Black Lives Matter
description: For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu.  Michelle C. Burroughs: director of community engagement and outreach for the Center for Healthy Communities. Burroughs is involved with the CHC’s engagement with the community focusing on the Black Lives Matter movement as well as social inequities. She is also a member of Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox’s Campus Safety Taskforce and the School of Medicine Diversity Committee.

title: Mobile clinics can help address health care needs of Latino farmworkers
description: A University of California, Riverside, study that sought to determine barriers to health care among Spanish-speaking Latino farmworkers in rural communities has devised an innovative health care service delivery model that addresses many challenges these communities face.

title: $10 sensor reduces brewers’ natural gas use
description: $45,000 UC Riverside investment helps researchers win $1.5 million grant

title: UCR ARTS celebrates new name, purpose
description: The newly renamed arts institution will bring enhanced programming and scholarship to downtown Riverside

title: Expanding the vision of queer dance
description: The two-day Explode! Queer Dance Festival will showcase artists from across the United States and around the world, featuring contemporary dance, improvisation, and drag.

title: Arts patron and UCR supporter Henry Coil dies at 85
description: Henry W. Coil Jr., a Riverside native and community booster whose construction firm and personal giving preserved historic buildings, built multiple schools and strengthened programs for young people and the arts, died October 3, 2018 at the age of 85.

title: Atmospheric seasons could signal alien life
description: UCR researchers are using seasonal changes in the Earth’s atmosphere to guide their search for life outside the solar system

title: Fall campaigns underway; fans look to basketball openings
description: Schedules are ongoing for many fall sports, with excitement building for the men's and women's basketball seasons, which begin later this fall and come on the heels of impressive 2021-22 campaigns for both. Following are early season reviews and pre-season previews for UC Riverside's fall sports teams.  All ticket purchases for UCR Athletics home events must be made online. Home games are free for UCR students with an R’Card.

title: One-dimensional material packs a powerful punch for next generation electronics
description: The new technology has applications in nanometer-scale transistors and circuits

title: Award-winning inventions improve electronics and renewable natural gas
description: Graphene thermal interface and steam hydrogasification receive TechConnect National Innovation Awards

title: UC Riverside joins new NSF center for the preservation of biological systems
description: The grant is the campus’ first successful bid for an NSF Engineering Research Center

title: Chemist receives Department of Energy award
description: Early Career Research Program award will support Ming Lee Tang’s research on developing hybrid organic-inorganic materials

title: Nobel Prize winner to join UC Riverside faculty
description: UCR alumnus and renowned scholar Richard Schrock will share pioneering science with faculty and students

title: An alternate theory for what causes Alzheimer's disease
description: A UC Riverside study points to lysosomal storage observed in all brains afflicted with the disease; finding could open up new avenues for treatment and prevention

title: Mystery of four-stranded DNA begins to unravel
description: DNA is usually depicted as double-stranded, but not much is known about parts of the genome that adopt four-stranded structures known as quadruplexes. UC Riverside researchers have discovered that they play a key role in keeping cells healthy.

title: Scientists discover potential cause of Alzheimer’s Disease
description: Prevailing theories posit plaques in the brain cause Alzheimer’s disease. New UC Riverside research points to cells’ slowing ability to clean themselves as the likely cause of unhealthy brain buildup.

title: Class of 2020: Remembered for ‘their flexibility and resilience’
description: UC Riverside’s 66th commencement will be a virtual celebration on Sunday, June 14. Meet some of the 2020 graduates.

title: Light-powered soft robots could suck up oil spills
description: A floating, robotic film designed at UC Riverside could be trained to hoover oil spills at sea or remove contaminants from drinking water.

title: No Thanksgiving for bacteria or fungus
description: UC Riverside scientists have developed a technique for solving a decades-old mystery involving the chemical in turkey that makes people sleepy. Their new ability to map the atoms involved in the production of tryptophan opens the door to new antibiotic and antifungal drugs.

title: The enduring power of art as activism in “Emory Douglas: Bold Visual Language”
description: Although the Black Panther Party dissolved nearly 40 years ago, the movement’s legacy endures — largely through the iconic imagery created by former party member Emory Douglas.

title: Injections for diabetes, cancer could become unnecessary
description: Researchers at UC Riverside are paving the way for diabetes and cancer patients to forget needles and injections, and instead take pills to manage their conditions.

title: Study links individual HPV types to HIV infection
description: UC Riverside-led study finds persons with any HPV type, more than one HPV type, or high-risk HPV are more likely to test HIV positive

title: Rewriting the textbook on how steroid hormones enter cells
description: Identification of a transporter that ferries steroids into cells could bring widespread benefits for human health

title: Research affirms the power of 'we'
description: A healthy relationship starts with the word “we.”  Past research by UC Riverside psychologist Megan Robbins has emphasized the power of first-person personal pronouns such as “we” and “us” in relationships. “We-talk” is an indicator of interdependence, meaning partners affect one another’s thoughts, feelings, and behaviors. This is a shift from self-oriented to relationship-oriented.

title: Students' summer impact
description: Summer break does not translate into idle hours for these three UC Riverside students.  For Bela Mendoza, a three-month summer internship with Riverside’s Operation SafeHouse, a youth emergency shelter, has given her an inside look at how to make a bigger — and more positive — impact in the lives of teens facing issues such as foster care, depression, homelessness, and human trafficking. At one point, she too experienced foster care and homelessness.

title: UCR celebrates 25 years of dance and scholarship
description: A Feb. 9 event commemorates the Department of Dance’s critical dance studies program. The day-long celebration will feature performances, talks, and roundtable discussions.

title: Venus might be habitable today, if not for Jupiter
description: Venus might not be a sweltering, waterless hellscape today if Jupiter hadn’t altered its orbit around the sun, according to new UC Riverside research.

title: University of California and Los Alamos National Laboratory researchers receive $3.6M to secure smart campuses
description: The project, co-led by UC Riverside and UCLA, will develop a holistic framework to enhance the security, privacy, and safety of campus operation

title: Sterilizing surgical masks for safer reuse
description: UC Riverside engineers are developing low-temperature plasma technology to sterilize masks

title: Silicone membranes create micron-scale temperature maps
description: Development could improve microfluidic devices used for point-of-care diagnostics

title: Double bubbles pierce with less trouble
description: Two optical cavitation bubbles penetrate soft materials better than one

title: Seeing inside superfog
description: High humidity and plant moisture combine with cold air and smoke from burning vegetation to form particularly dense fog, but researchers can’t predict when

title: Lasers can weld ceramics without a furnace
description: Ultrafast pulsed lasers fuse ceramics under ambient conditions and use less than 50 watts of power

title: Alzheimer's gene may impact cognition before adulthood
description: A gene linked to Alzheimer’s disease may impact cognitive health much sooner than previously realized. The APOE gene creates a protein, apolipoprotein E, which packages cholesterol and other fats to transport them through the bloodstream. There are three versions, or alleles, of APOE. One of those is the APOE4 allele, present in about 15% of the population. APOE4 carriers are up to three times more likely to develop late-onset Alzheimer’s disease, which occurs in people 65 and older.

title: Study of perception and memory in older adults will improve understanding of dementias
description: UC Riverside scientists will use a $2 million NIH grant to study the brain’s locus coeruleus

title: National Magazine Honors Program focused on diversifying STEM fields
description: UC Riverside Bridges to the Baccalaureate Program receives 2018 Inspiring Programs in STEM Award from INSIGHT Into Diversity magazine

title: Hope on the horizon for treating stroke
description: UC Riverside biomedical scientist’s decades-long work moves to clinical trials

title: Federal grant will help develop new stroke treatment
description: The device aims to reduce brain swelling and deliver a neuroprotective drug

title: $370,000 gift to support UCR’s Young Oak Kim Center for Korean American Studies
description: The donation comes from Myung Ki “Mike” Hong, a longtime advocate of the center and other initiatives related to Korean American affairs

title: UC Riverside launches research center to drive Inland California innovation
description: The Center for Social Innovation will use university-level research to spur community involvement and civic participation

title: $1 million grant reaffirms UCR’s commitment to the humanities
description: The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation’s gift leverages campaign support to fund 26 faculty fellowships at the Center for Ideas and Society

title: Pioneering a pathway to success for STEM teachers
description: Collaboration between UCR and Riverside Unified School District yields scholarship fund, job placements for newly minted STEM teachers

title: New data science major promotes diversity in high-tech
description: Program will build new educational pathways in computing or technology for students, especially women, who otherwise would not study these subjects in college

title: Donation brings zero-emissions vehicles one step closer to reality
description: New light-duty emissions testing facility gives UC Riverside the inside track toward the goal of zero-emission vehicles

title: Summer internships — from home
description: These UCR students aren’t letting a pandemic stop their personal and professional development.

title: A different type of holiday party for Guardian Scholars
description: The program works to make the holidays special for foster youth, despite the pandemic’s challenges.

title: Botnet buster finds IoT command and control centers
description: Tool fools malware twice and can trick it into revealing itself

title: SourceFinder software stalks malware in the wild
description: UC Riverside computer scientists develop tool to locate malware source code repositories

title: New Spectre cyberthreat evades patches
description: New speculative execution attack launches from a computer’s return stack buffer, not the branch predictor

title: Acclaimed industry designer Scott Saltsman presents summer youth workshop in video game design
description: Gear-up for a future in technology at UCR Extension and UCR Palm Desert

title: New security flaw discovered in Wi-Fi routers
description: Hackers can use your wireless router to extract information, and there’s not much you can do to stop them

title: Business size matters when it comes to economic growth
description: New analysis finds small businesses are powering establishment growth, but medium and large firms contribute more to job gains

title: UCR offers media diverse voices on diverse topics
description: TOPICS CLIMATE CHANGE, AIR QUALITY, GREEN ENERGY, SUSTAINABILITY NATURAL DISASTERS HEALTH PHYSICS

title: Brian Haynes to be appointed UCR Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs
description: Career Public University Administrator is Currently Head of Student Affairs at Cal State San Bernardino

title: Worker scarcity, rising home prices push up against an economy in growth mode
description: Building and construction spending, permitting rises as home demand intensifies

title: Free dataset archive helps researchers quickly find a needle in a haystack
description: UCR STAR visualizes public spatio-temporal datasets through an interactive map

title: Brian Haynes to be appointed UCR Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs
description: Administrator is currently head of Student Affairs at Cal State San Bernardino

title: UC Riverside Fall 2018 admissions show surge in transfer student numbers
description: In two years, UCR transfer applications have climbed by 23 percent.

title: New funding will help UCR diversify physician workforce in inland Southern California
description: The California Wellness Foundation has awarded the School of Medicine a $450,000 grant

title: Natural gas engine can reduce smog from heavy-duty trucks
description: Simulated on-road testing shows the engine maintains near-zero emissions during all duty cycles

title: First comprehensive fundraising campaign nears its end
description: UC Riverside is closing in on the end of its first-ever comprehensive fundraising campaign. The total raised through August 23 was $298,116,805.

title: Living the Promise campaign hits $300 million goal
description: UC Riverside surpassed its $300 million goal on Sept. 10 for its first comprehensive fundraising campaign, “Living the Promise: The Campaign for UC Riverside.” Although the overall dollar goal has been reached, the campaign isn’t yet over. The effort, which was publicly launched on October 15, 2016, will close on Dec. 31, 2020, and university fundraisers hope to encourage greater participation from UCR alumni and friends, particularly in support of students.

title: Creating a healthy racial climate to diversify the teacher workforce
description: Paper offers a framework for racial literacy in teacher education

title: Meet the educator building bridges between teachers of color
description: A UCR professor’s annual institute seeks to turn isolation — a fact of life for teachers of color across the country — into action

title: UC Riverside’s FIERCE Scholars are diversifying the Inland Empire teacher workforce
description: A gift from SchoolsFirst Federal Credit Union to UC Riverside School of Education is funding a program to get local education students into graduate or credential programs

title: Machines whisper our secrets
description: Spies can learn what a machine is making from the sounds it makes

title: New attacks on graphics processors endanger user privacy
description: Hackers can use the graphics processing unit to spy on web activity, steal passwords, and break into cloud-based applications

title: Inland Empire tech industry should focus on local strengths
description: Growth efforts should link to logisitics, agriculture, and green tech

title: UCR Palm Desert’s MFA celebrates 10th anniversary
description: What has made this low residency, self-sustaining program successful, can be attributed to three factors: it embraces fiction genre writing, it teaches students the business aspect of writing, and is driven by student success, boasting a publication/production rate of more than 75 percent within two years of graduating.

title: UCR Extension offers new series of STEM workshops based on the makerspace ideology
description: Join the 'Maker Movement' for hands-on learning the Makerspace way

title: Building a stronger community through partnerships
description: UCR Extension's Kasey Wilson leads the way

title: Detection of very high frequency magnetic resonance could revolutionize electronics
description: UC Riverside-led research has applications in ultrafast and spin-based nanoscale devices

title: Join UCR faculty and alumni at the LA Times Festival of Books
description: Attend panel discussions and book signings featuring UCR writers at the USC campus April 13-14.

title: This computer scientist beats hackers at their own game
description: Fatemah Alharbi discovered a serious security flaw, earning thanks from Apple

title: UC Riverside gets $2.5 million for Inland Empire’s first entrepreneurial life sciences incubator
description: Life sciences startups will have local wet lab space and guidance from experts

title: Governor’s initiative misunderstands inland California’s economies
description: ‘Regions Rise Together’ comparison to coastal regions may distort policy direction

title: How to block eavesdropping on wireless communications
description: Confusing channel state information offers a first line of defense in full-duplex wireless

title: $3 million grant aims to prolong life for dialysis patients
description: The five-year survival rate for people on dialysis is under 50 percent. University of California researchers are hoping to improve that prognosis.

title: Does the presence of colleges and hospitals increase home prices?
description: The institution’s size and the ZIP code’s population can have positive and negative effects

title: Building the future for UCR's School of Business
description: Beverly Bailey knows a thing or two about building things.  As a student at Riverside City College, she helped her boyfriend Scott hang patio covers on the weekends. When she turned 20, she bought and ran a small café in Chino, putting her entrepreneurial spirit to the test as she worked some of the longest days of her life. Then she earned her real estate license, making a living helping people build their dream homes.

title: Gift to School of Medicine aims to alleviate inland Southern California’s physician shortage
description: Inland Empire Health Plan’s gift of $2.6M will create up to 23 awards designed to encourage students to practice in the region

title: Musical sensor shows bad medicine plays false note
description: Inspired by a musical instrument, the simple sensor can be constructed from common materials and used to detect adulterated or counterfeit drugs

title: Nutrient-recycling microbes may feel the heat
description: Study led by UCR researcher explores how climate change affects nature’s ability to recycle

title: UCR faculty member's book shares stories of teachers of color
description: “What are you … on their side?” The comment was one of many snarky remarks white teachers made about interactions between a Latino colleague and his diverse student population. In the staff lounge at the Sacramento, Calif., public school, the same teachers called the students “monkeys bouncing off the walls” and “losers.” The Latino teacher pushed back. But he reached a point where it was so frustrating to be in the lounge that he stopped going.

title: Seeing through food and drug fakes and frauds
description: “Chronoprints” can identify a sample from a video taken as it reacts to disturbance

title: ‘Real Women Have Curves’ director joins UCR faculty
description: This fall, Cardoso joined UCR’ Department of Theatre, Film, and Digital Production and is currently teaching two courses. The Colombian-born creator said she felt identified to the students and to UCR’s mission.

title: Microchips can permanently link patients with clinical samples
description: Project to embed patient data directly in biological samples receives Gates Foundation funding

title: Simple new testing method aims to improve time-release drugs
description: Glass tuning-fork-shaped tubing gives accurate, continuous measurements of drug dissolution

title: Earthquakes, chickens, and bugs, oh my!
description: New big data algorithms improve earthquake detection; monitor livestock health and agricultural pests

title: Air-powered computer memory helps soft robot control movements
description: “Airhead” robot uses pneumatic RAM to play piano

title: Can I mix those chemicals? There’s an app for that!
description: New technology can find the safest way to store and dispose of reactive chemicals

title: Governor’s budget proposal allocates $25 million for UCR School of Medicine
description: Additional ongoing funding would help the medical school expand enrollment

title: Wildfire dataset could help firefighters save lives and property
description: WildfireDB contains over 17 million data points that capture how fires have spread in the contiguous United States over the last decade

title: State OKs $25M to double UCR medical students
description: Budget allocates ongoing funding to the medical school

title: Entrepreneurship incubator boosts Inland Empire biotech startups
description: UC Riverside’s Wet Lab Incubator, the first of its kind in the region, has officially opened its doors

title: Federal Economic Development Administration invests in Inland Empire entrepreneurship
description: Latest grant to UC Riverside will create an angel investor network to take regional tech startups to the next level

title: Why don’t veterans share their stories?
description: What ma

title: David Leonhardt presents Feb. 27 Hays P-E Lecture
description: New York Times columnist David Leonhardt will offer the Feb. 27 Hays Press-Enterprise Lecture, which will take place between 4-6 p.m. at the UC Riverside Extension Center.

title: Highlander venture fund makes its first investment
description: $250,000 supports San Diego-based NanoCellect Biomedical Inc.

title: UCR’s first family makes new commitment to support students
description: Chancellor Kim Wilcox and his wife, Diane Del Buono, previously created the 13th Chancellor’s Research Fellowship

title: Endowed gift will broaden the horizon for UCR students
description: A $2 million gift from the Pollitt family will fund scholarships that support study abroad opportunities.

title: Want to know L.A.'s Latinx story? Follow the music posters
description: Beginning around 1990, the demographic landscape of the Los Angeles area changed dramatically through an infusion of immigrants from Mexico and Central America. But historian Jorge Leal says its impact on the neighborhoods of the Los Angeles area has never been charted in earnest. With his recently published research, Leal has taken a furtive step into documenting the Latinx community’s emerging L.A. footprint, using an unconventional source. If you want to know about the Latinx community’s presence in L.A. over the past 30 years, Leal says to follow the music posters.

title: PCORI award seeks to support students in recovery
description: Project is the first major effort in the UC system to assess the needs of students in recovery

title: Implantable piezoelectric polymer improves controlled release of drugs
description: Repeated tests showed a similar amount of drug release per activation, confirming robust control of release rate

title: A new approach to targeting cancer cells
description: UC Riverside researchers develop new drugs that target therapeutically relevant protein surfaces

title: Addiction Medicine Fellowship program receives initial accreditation
description: The first class of fellows begins training in the Coachella Valley’s Betty Ford Center and Eisenhower Medical Center on July 1

title: Scientists profile FDA-approved drugs to potentially treat hundreds of genetic disorders
description: New method developed by UC Riverside researchers quickly assesses drug potential for rare disorders

title: Scientists identify hundreds of drug candidates to treat COVID-19
description: UC Riverside researchers used a powerful machine-learning approach to screen millions of chemicals to find suitable candidates

title: Elizabeth Watkins to be appointed UCR provost and EVC
description: UC Riverside Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox announced the appointment of Elizabeth Watkins as provost and executive vice chancellor effective May 1, 2021, pending approval by University of California President Michael Drake. Watkins has extensive experience as a University of California administrator, faculty member, and leader in the Academic Senate.

title: New Vice Provost & Dean of Graduate Studies named
description: Lidia Kos has been named UC Riverside’s next vice provost & dean of graduate studies, or VPDGS, effective July 15, 2023.

title: Highlander Venture Fund chooses UCR professor’s ‘next-generation’ mosquito repellent for second investment
description: Up to $500,000 will help a startup company market a killer repellent that’s nontoxic, natural, and sweet-smelling

title: Rodolfo H. Torres to be appointed Vice Chancellor for Research and Economic Development
description: Torres is a distinguished mathematician whose work has been supported by the National Science Foundation

title: Inland Empire business activity jumps following first quarter slowdown
description: New analysis reveals region’s most and least competitive industries

title: University of Maryland scholar is UCR’s next CHASS dean
description: Daryle Williams is a historian who co-directs the online database Enslaved.org.

title: Veterans history project receives VA funding through 2020
description: Federal funding will enable thousands more Inland Empire K-12 students to join in documenting the histories of those interred at Riverside National Cemetery

title: UC Riverside crests 76% for six-year graduation rate
description: In the past six years, UC Riverside's six-year graduation rate has improved by 10 percentage points

title: UC Riverside-led project offers new opportunities to commemorate veterans
description: Several resources, including a series of documentary vignettes, provides visitors numerous ways to enhance their own Veterans Day celebrations

title: Robot sleeves for kids with cerebral palsy
description: UC Riverside engineers are developing low-cost, robotic “clothing” to help children with cerebral palsy gain control over their arm movements.

title: Boyle Heights: Cemented in history
description: Capturing the essence of a place requires more than time. It requires confianza. Trust.    That’s why for more than a year a team co-led by a UC Riverside cultural and urban historian interviewed, researched, and documented the lives of Boyle Heights residents — all in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic. For centuries, Boyle Heights, a community three miles east of downtown Los Angeles, has been home to generations of immigrants and social justice movements.

title: Researchers use a molecular trojan horse to deliver chemotherapeutic drug to cancer cells
description: A UCR research team has discovered a way for chemotherapy drug paclitaxel to target migrating cancer cells

title: UC Riverside researchers find potent chemical agents that can thwart cancer metastasis
description: Novel agents 135H11 and 135H12 move research closer to drug development

title: New funding to significantly boost cancer, ALS research
description: UC Riverside’s Maurizio Pellecchia receives grants totaling nearly $2.5 million from National Academy of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine; and National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

title: Grant will help engineer human-like nerve tissue
description: The tissue will be used to study neurological diseases

title: Fundraising effort seeks to aid at-risk Afghan scholars
description: Public donations will help scholars fleeing from danger, offer them safety .

title: Inland Empire business activity takes a nosedive
description: Pandemic highlights strain on households with children

title: Inland Empire business activity outpacing U.S. GDP growth
description: Local manufacturing industry remains a key growth sector

title: Biologists decipher a key piece of the odor-detection puzzle in flies, mosquitoes
description: UC Riverside basic discovery offers path to safer products to protect against disease-carrying mosquitoes, chemicals to control crop-damaging pests

title: The new provost is ready to get started
description: Elizabeth Watkins is UC Riverside's new provost and executive vice chancellor. The provost is eager to help raise the profile and funding support for UCR's research enterprise, and to work with its high-achieving students — this past year, UCR set a new six-year graduation rate record — many of whom are first-generation students, and from underrepresented and low-income families.

title: Scientists identify how plants sense temperature
description: When it gets hot outside, humans and animals have the luxury of seeking shelter in the shade or cool, air-conditioned buildings. But plants are stuck. While not immune to changing climate, plants respond to the rising mercury in different ways. Temperature affects the distribution of plants around the planet. It also affects the flowering time, crop yield, and even resistance to disease.

title: Research offers superior therapeutic approach for MS
description: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease that affects more than 2.3 million people worldwide. This debilitating condition periodically shutters communication between the brain and other parts of the body, resulting in symptoms that range from numbness and tingling in the arms and legs to blindness and paralysis. While treatments are available to alleviate inflammation, no therapies exist to protect neurons or repair the degraded myelin sheath that normally surrounds nerves.

title: Researchers explore why some MS patients experience seizures
description: UC Riverside study examines molecular pathways that may instigate seizures in some multiple sclerosis patients

title: Not so quiet, please
description: UC Riverside mouse study finds early exposure to sounds can address hypersensitivity to noise associated with Fragile X Syndrome

title: New book explores how plague shaped Christianity in the Americas
description: During the first century of American colonization, as many as 20 million people in Mexico perished from disease, violence, and exploitation. Jennifer Scheper Hughes, a professor in the Department of History at the University of California, Riverside, examines this period from historical and theological perspectives in her new book, “The Church of the Dead: The Epidemic of 1576 and the Birth of Christianity in the Americas.”

title: Study finds natural selection favors cheaters
description: UC Riverside research focused on interaction between nitrogen-fixing bacteria and their hosts

title: Men's Basketball tramples Cornhuskers in season opener
description: LINCOLN, NEB.- For the second time in three years, the UC Riverside Men's Basketball Team (1-0) opened its season on the road with a big win over a power five conference team. Tuesday night, the Highlanders roasted the Cornhuskers (0-1) from Nebraska 66-47, marking the program's largest margin of victory on opening night against a DI opponent, and the first time the Huskers have lost their home opener since 1980.

title: Historian’s database offers new view of colonial California
description: Through his Pobladores Project, Steven Hackel spotlights the non-American Indian settlers and soldiers who lived in California between 1769 and 1850

title: Approaching the Vietnam War from another angle
description: An environmental historian’s book highlights the roles landscapes play in military conflicts

title: This UCR historian once trained horses; now she studies them
description: Doctoral student Katrin Boniface turns a lifelong passion into research for a growing field: equine history

title: $1 million grant advances study of California’s missions
description: Funding will connect UC scholars across campuses to launch an entirely new field: Critical Mission Studies

title: This deep neural network fights deepfakes
description: Artificial intelligence to accurately detect altered photos is getting smarter

title: New UC Riverside research advances spintronics technology
description: Discoveries will help realize the promise of faster, energy-efficient spintronic computers and ultra-high-capacity data storage

title: Online sites fight back against blocked ads
description: UCR research finds an astonishing 52 times more anti-ad blocking than previously thought

title: UC Riverside physicists create exotic electron liquid
description: The first production of an electron liquid at room temperature opens the way for new optoelectronic devices and basic physics studies

title: Economic turmoil expected through second quarter of 2020
description: COVID-19 will deliver a blow but how bad it will be is yet to be seen

title: New economic outlook optimistic but warns of ‘wild cards’ that could send things spiraling
description: A second outbreak will have even worse damage

title: This is how our economy can survive the pandemic
description: Economist Gloria González-Rivera offers insight on how to limit damage

title: UCR dance professor receives 2019 Bessie Award
description: This is the second such honor for Ni’Ja Whitson.

title: Going with the floe: Sea ice movements trace dynamics transforming the new Arctic
description: Image processing algorithms on satellite images show how sea ice drift affects freshwater flux in Arctic Ocean currents

title: Chemical compound produces beneficial inflammation and remyelination that could help treat multiple sclerosis
description: UC Riverside-led study shows that ‘good inflammation’ promotes axon myelination

title: Often-overlooked glial cell is key to learning and memory
description: UC Riverside biomedical scientists offer simple advice: keep the brain active

title: Brain protein linked to seizures, abnormal social behaviors
description: UC Riverside mouse study focused on neurons in the hippocampus

title: More than half of American adults with advanced multiple sclerosis report mistreatment by caregivers
description: UC Riverside-led study describes first published survey documenting nature and extent of caregiver mistreatment of this population

title: Star-shaped brain cells may be linked to stuttering
description: UC Riverside-led study examined the effects of the medication risperidone on brain metabolism in stuttering
